title: Paul Gascoigne breaks down on GMB over his 'horrendous' sex assault trial hell
text:

Paul Gascoigne was left in tears on Good Morning Britain on Wednesday, as he opened up on his "year of hell" after being accused of sexual assault on a train earlier this year.

Gazza was cleared of all charges in court following a trial, with him speaking out on TV for the first time on the incident.

He told hosts Ben Shephard and Kate Garraway about what happened on the train with the lady who accused him, sharing his shock over the accusations.

As he revealed how he coped in the fallout, the football legend broke down as he said how the situation was a major test following years of battling an alcohol addiction - with him currently six months sober.

(Image: ITV)

He tearfully told the hosts: "It did get hard walking around street... sorry," before being too overwhelmed to speak.

Kate got him some tissues, as the star admitted the support from fans who believed him got him through.

He added: "I think I spent the whole year telling people I did nothing wrong... sorry."

(Image: PA)

Gazza admitted to "pecking" a lady on a train on the lips after a man on the same train called her "fat and ugly", and said he didn't mean it "sexually".

He said that after telling her this wasn't the case, wanting to give her a "confidence boost", he gave her a "peck" - which he told police in his statement.

After initially thinking nothing of the incident, he was stunned to be told that police needed to speak to him about it, and he was soon facing a court case.

(Image: ITV)

His pal and host Ben admitted finding it "difficult" watching his recent struggle, with him and Kate praising the fact he didn't turn back to drink during one of his hardest times.

On the moment he worried about what could happen, he said: "[I wasn't worried] at first.

"I think I was more scared when I sat down with my lawyers and they told me, I did get a bit worried."

(Image: ITV)

Gazza said he was "more cautious" of people now following the situation, and revealed he'd remained sober throughout the "horrendous" ordeal.

He said: "Most people would go out and celebrate but I didn't feel I had anything to celebrate. I'd say the rest of my life depended on this."

Gazza also feared for the work opportunities he has lined up, with those jobs resting on the result of his court case - while he's confirmed they will still go ahead.

Good Morning Britain airs weekdays at 6am on ITV.
description: Paul Gascoigne, known as Gazza, was cleared of sexual assault charges in court this month, with him fighting back tears as he discussed his 'year of hell'
